Defense and Travel, Logistics & Infrastructure Practices.</div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Many companies across the aviation value chain have set goals to be completed over the long term, but there are actions they can take today to move closer to accomplishing these objectives. To get started, companies should understand which actions to prioritize for the greatest impact and for a cost-optimal path to net-zero emissions.</p>
<h2>The current state of aviation decarbonization</h2>
<p>Prepandemic CO<sub>2</sub> emissions from aviation contributed to roughly 2.5 percent of global total emissions,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ff788800-c229-4f89-931b-26caf83ca9ee"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ff788800-c229-4f89-931b-26caf83ca9ee" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Future Air Mobility</em>, ‚Äú<a href="/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/future-air-mobility-blog/fuel-efficiency-why-airlines-need-to-switch-to-more-ambitious-measures">Fuel efficiency: Why airlines need to switch to more ambitious measures</a>,‚Äù blog entry by Axel Esqu√©, Guenter Fuchs, and Robin Riedel, McKinsey, March 1, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> but the global-warming potential could be significantly greater (see sidebar ‚ÄúAviation and non-CO<sub>2</sub> emissions‚Äù). The sector is hard to abate because of unique requirements, including weight and size constraints, long innovation cycles, prioritization of safe operations, and because key technologies, such as SAFs, are relatively costly and have not been adopted at scale.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d08c9ad2-eee5-4a26-97c5-2162af82d9e3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d08c9ad2-eee5-4a26-97c5-2162af82d9e3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Axel Esqu√©, Adam Mitchell, Kritika Rastogi, and Robin Riedel, ‚Äú<a href="/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/decarbonizing-the-aviation-sector-making-net-zero-aviation-possible">Decarbonizing the aviation sector: Making net zero aviation possible</a>,‚Äù McKinsey July 15, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>In addition to the CO<sub>2</sub> emissions produced from burning fuel, aviation affects the climate through emissions of nitrogen oxides (NO<sub>x</sub>), soot, and water vapor, which, among other effects, create contrails and cirrus clouds that cause radiation and affect the climate. The CO<sub>2</sub> emitted from kerosene burned in flight can stay in the upper atmosphere for 50 to 100 years, and NO<sub>x</sub> remain for several weeks, affecting the ozone layer.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2647cf7d-bbc2-49e8-89d9-55aa2e4cbe31"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2647cf7d-bbc2-49e8-89d9-55aa2e4cbe31" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Hydrogen-powered aviation: A fact-based study of hydrogen technology, economics, and climate impact by 2050</em>, a joint report from the Clean Sky 2 and Fuel Cells and Hydrogen 2 Joint Undertakings, May 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> As such, the total aviation effects may be approximately two to four times higher than the pure CO<sub>2</sub> effects would indicate.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f956f8bb-df5b-4f66-927e-e4445ad65676"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f956f8bb-df5b-4f66-927e-e4445ad65676" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Target true zero unlocking sustainable battery and hydrogen-powered flight</em>, World Economic Forum (WEF), July 2022; M. R. Allen et al., ‚ÄúThe contribution of global aviation to anthropogenic climate forcing for 2000 to 2018,‚Äù <em>Atmospheric Environment</em>, January 2021, Volume 244.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The science on non-CO<sub>2</sub> effects is nascent, so most airlines (and the latest Science Based Target initiative guidance) refer only to pure CO<sub>2</sub> emissions.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Many stakeholders in the aviation value chain have committed to various sustainability goals, including emission-reduction targets,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="54995976-cd1b-4c85-befd-7c809d5ade5a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="54995976-cd1b-4c85-befd-7c809d5ade5a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúEnvironmental sustainability goals,‚Äù Southwest, accessed May 25, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> SAF targets,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9e62c62a-d913-469b-b5c9-09572c8cc024"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9e62c62a-d913-469b-b5c9-09572c8cc024" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúDHL class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4d856995-fbe5-48c6-8ead-104cef3d9b7c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span including net-zero carbon emissions by 2040,‚Äù Alaska Airlines, April 21, 2021; ‚ÄúHawaiian Airlines commits to new milestones on path to net-zero carbon emissions,‚Äù Hawaiian Airlines, March 30, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> and membership in coalitions.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e39c27ba-d699-4fc4-ae10-9fd116c601dc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e39c27ba-d699-4fc4-ae10-9fd116c601dc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúLufthansa joins first movers coalition to drive global development of sustainable aviation fuels,‚Äù WEF, March 28, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> In addition to the defined paths to reduce emissions that are in line with the Paris Agreement, the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi) has emerged as one of the leading standards (see sidebar ‚ÄúThe Science Based Targets initiative‚Äù).</p>

data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_79c2a62 mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>The Science Based Targets initiative</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>The Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi) is a collaboration among four nongovernmental organizations: Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP), the United Nations Global Compact, World Resources Institute (WRI), and the World Wildlife Fund for Nature (WWF). The initiative aims to ensure emission-reduction targets set by companies are within the pace recommended by scientists to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. It also provides guidance and promotes best practices to reduce corporate greenhouse-gas emissions. As of April 2023, more than 4,500 companies have committed to or set science-based targets.</p>
<p>Recently, the SBTi has provided guidance for an interim aviation 1.5¬∞ pathway, implying strict emission-reduction targets for airlines: namely, a more than 30 percent CO<sub>2</sub> reduction per revenue ton kilometer (RTK) by 2030 compared to 2019 base year levels and a more than 50 percent reduction by 2035.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9a061a15-694a-47b5-b885-eb8969fdea92"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9a061a15-694a-47b5-b885-eb8969fdea92" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Base year and target year vary by airline.</span></span></span></a></span><sup>,</sup> <span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1210d5e3-1326-49aa-8e42-5b0f7711e58d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1210d5e3-1326-49aa-8e42-5b0f7711e58d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Technical report: The SBTi interim 1.5¬∞ sector pathway for Aviation</em>, Science Based Targets, February 2023. </span></span></span></a></span> In comparison, the International Energy Agency Net Zero Emissions pathway calls for approximately 38 percent emission reduction in 2030 and approximately 57 percent in 2035 compared to 2019 levels. Note that both pathways set targets for relative emissions only (measured per RTK).</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>As of April 2023, 25 airlines‚Äîmostly based in the Americas and Europe‚Äîhave committed to setting or have set science-based targets. According to McKinsey analysis, this group represents more than 30 percent of global passenger traffic. On the OEM side, aerospace and defense companies, representing about 20 percent of the global value pool, have also committed to goals aligned with SBTi (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_79c2a62 mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/aerospace%20and%20defense/our%20insights/decarbonizing%20aviation%20executing%20on%20net%20zero%20goals/svgz-decarbonizing-aviation-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The number of airlines and aerospace and defense companies committed to Science Based Targets initiative‚Äìaligned climate goals is growing." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/aerospace%20and%20defense/our%20insights/decarbonizing%20aviation%20executing%20on%20net%20zero%20goals/svgz-decarbonizing-aviation-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>While the ambitions are clear, actors in the aviation sector are highly dependent on each other to achieve their decarbonization commitments. For example, more than 95 percent of aircraft OEMs‚Äô emissions come from their Scope 3 Category 11 downstream emissions,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b3e7ad86-4235-4c14-b4c3-ae9c758dede2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b3e7ad86-4235-4c14-b4c3-ae9c758dede2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Scope 3 Category 11 emissions are released when sold products are used by the consumer.</span></span></span></a></span><sup>,</sup> <span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7ee0ced0-1f83-4314-8d48-fc4a6c4cd65d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7ee0ced0-1f83-4314-8d48-fc4a6c4cd65d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Future Air Mobility</em>, ‚Äú<a href="/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/future-air-mobility-blog/a-dual-approach-to-decarbonization-in-aerospace">A dual approach to decarbonization in aerospace</a>,‚Äù blog post by McKinsey, July 18, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> which is mostly airlines‚Äô fuel burn. This interdependency has strengthened the industry‚Äôs unified ambition to decarbonize, but it also highlights the role that actors such as commercial aviation lessors, OEMs, and suppliers need to play to support airlines and offer solutions.</p>
<h2>Factors affecting decarbonization</h2>
<p>Options for airlines to abate CO<sub>2</sub> emissions differ based on existing fleet efficiency, the network of the airline, and the baseline decarbonization efforts already implemented by the airline.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>From a technology perspective, the development to scale new SAF pathways with improved emission-reduction potential, such as advanced biofuels or power to liquid (PtL) fuels, is uncertain.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ccd71d95-db96-4aea-987a-6419401044d6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ccd71d95-db96-4aea-987a-6419401044d6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Bernd Heid, Nathan Lash, Robin Riedel, and Daniel Riefer, ‚Äú<a href="/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/clean-skies-for-tomorrow-delivering-on-the-global-power-to-liquid-ambition">Clean skies for tomorrow: Delivering on the global power-to-liquid ambition</a>,‚Äù McKinsey, August 25, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Biobased pathways face challenges in feedstock availability and collection to be immediately scalable, and PtL requires significant access to large amounts of renewable electricity. Other uncertainties remain about the progress in other technologies fields, such as new propulsion technology or advanced analytics for flight planning.</p>
<p>From a regulatory perspective, aviation players will need to adapt to the ever-changing implementation of regional incentives and penalties. For example, Europe‚Äôs reaction to the Inflation Reduction Act could change SAF-related decarbonization costs for European airlines.</p>
<p>Other industries such as marine and road transport, which are sourcing from the same sustainable fuel feedstock, also influence the aviation sector. This competition affects the balance of SAF supply and demand and therefore its market price, especially as the regulatory schemes and customer willingness to pay evolve.</p>
<p>Many decarbonization efforts also require investments with longer lead times that are not in line with traditional airline yearly business planning cycles and, as such, require a different view on economic and environmental returns. Although many airlines have shown strong financial results in 2022, outlooks are uncertain as the industry returns to pre-COVID-19 capacity levels, which drives traditional airlines to limit riskier investments despite their potential payoff beyond five-year financial plans.</p>
<p>These external factors have contributed to the struggle of companies across the aviation ecosystem to deploy multiple decarbonization efforts in the most cost-effective way, while managing uncertainties in parallel.</p>
<h2>Introducing the marginal abatement cost curve</h2>
<p>As the timeline to hit near-term emission targets shortens, aviation sector players are increasingly searching for ways to achieve these goals‚Äîand do so quickly to compensate for the long lead times of many initiatives. For example, solidifying sufficient access to affordable SAF can take several years, and renewing fleet quickly depends on OEMs‚Äô or lessors‚Äô ability to deliver or provide new aircraft.</p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit </span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top <p>Initiatives are organized left to right on the marginal abatement cost curve (MACC) based on the economic cost of the initiative‚Äôs emissions abatement. Leveraging the MACC, airlines can execute decarbonization initiatives by implementing cost-negative initiatives first, such as those that save fuel.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>As a first step, airlines can evaluate carbon abatement costs and impact potential by developing their own marginal abatement cost curve (MACC).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c2a272ca-1cbf-45e6-9e79-9af0b8b932fa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c2a272ca-1cbf-45e6-9e79-9af0b8b932fa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For a perspective on how McKinsey has been using the MACC, see <em>New at McKinsey Blog</em>, ‚Äú<a href="/about-us/new-at-mckinsey-blog/a-revolutionary-tool-for-cutting-emissions-ten-years-on">A revolutionary tool for cutting emissions, ten years on</a>,‚Äù blog entry by McKinsey, April 21, 2017.</span></span></span></a></span> This assessment helps companies compare and sequence different decarbonization measures while also allowing for adjustments and updates. It also helps companies determine the best and most cost-effective decarbonization solutions for the industry (see sidebar ‚ÄúReading a marginal abatement cost curve‚Äù).</p>
<h3>Categories within a typical MACC for airlines</h3>
<p>Exhibit 2 illustrates a typical MACC for an airline. Actions are classified by three categories: operational measures (including air traffic management), fleet renewal, and SAF.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_79c2a62 mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/aerospace%20and%20defense/our%20insights/decarbonizing%20aviation%20executing%20on%20net%20zero%20goals/svgz-decarbonizing-aviation-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Airlines‚Äô marginal abatement cost curves typically include actions in three areas." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/aerospace%20and%20defense/our%20insights/decarbonizing%20aviation%20executing%20on%20net%20zero%20goals/svgz-decarbonizing-aviation-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p><strong><em>Operational measures.</em></strong> Operational and efficiency measures often come at negative or low costs (due to associated fuel savings) but are limited in their impact.</p>
<p>Airlines can relatively easily enforce initiatives within their own control, such as introducing pilot incentive programs to fly and taxi more fuel efficiently or imposing stricter operational weight limits to reduce fuel needs. Bolder moves could affect customer experiences, such as reducing ultra-long-haul flights, removing some catering on short-haul flights, or densifying cabins to include more seats.</p>
<p>Other efficiency efforts are dependent on collaboration among several stakeholders, especially to optimize air space usage. For example, the Single European Sky program<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fc338fbc-a2ad-4ad2-bd3c-976c80b1a5cd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fc338fbc-a2ad-4ad2-bd3c-976c80b1a5cd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúSingle European Sky,‚Äù European Commission, accessed May 25, 2023; Sesar Joint Undertaking website.</span></span></span></a></span> aims to modernize air traffic control infrastructure to reduce up to 10 percent of emissions,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8bee0b94-05be-4539-9808-9cdcc54fa415"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8bee0b94-05be-4539-9808-9cdcc54fa415" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúSingle European Sky: for a more sustainable and resilient air traffic management,‚Äù European Commission, September 22, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> and a similar program called NextGen<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="15cc1f22-c152-4c3b-9f54-146776bf63fb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="15cc1f22-c152-4c3b-9f54-146776bf63fb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúNext Generation Air Transportation System (NextGen),‚Äù Federal Aviation Administration, updated May 12, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> is underway in the United States. However, an airline‚Äôs actual carbon emission savings depend on its exposure to the affected airspace, and emission reductions could be significantly lower than 10 percent.</p>
<p><strong><em>Fleet renewal.</em></strong> Accelerated fleet rollover can come at negative marginal abatement cost, particularly when including the impact of regulatory action, such as future SAF mandates and kerosene taxes. Depending on the state of an airline‚Äôs fleet, the evolutionary rollover to already available aircraft types represents a decarbonization potential of up to 15 to 20 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ff0286a4-de0d-4cf8-aafa-17f83ef5fda7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ff0286a4-de0d-4cf8-aafa-17f83ef5fda7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Future Air Mobility</em>, ‚Äú<a href="/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/future-air-mobility-blog/fuel-efficiency-why-airlines-need-to-switch-to-more-ambitious-measures">Fuel efficiency: Why airlines need to switch to more ambitious measures</a>,‚Äù blog entry by Axel Esqu√©, Guenter Fuchs, and Robin Riedel, McKinsey, March 1, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> It is expected that next-generation aircraft, such as the Airbus A320neo or the Boeing 777-X family, will replace a significant share of current-generation aircraft in the next ten years (Exhibit 3).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_79c2a62 mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/aerospace%20and%20defense/our%20insights/decarbonizing%20aviation%20executing%20on%20net%20zero%20goals/svgz-decarbonizing-aviation-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Next-generation aircraft are expected to replace a significant share of current-generation aircraft in the next ten years." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/aerospace%20and%20defense/our%20insights/decarbonizing%20aviation%20executing%20on%20net%20zero%20goals/svgz-decarbonizing-aviation-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>In the long term, both OEMs and airlines could benefit from transitioning to more fuel-efficient aircraft and could adjust their prices to reflect greater fuel efficiency.</p>
<p><strong><em>SAF.</em></strong> SAF is by far the most impactful initiative, but financial effects vary due to mandates, subsidies, sourcing approaches, voluntary commitments, and customers‚Äô willingness to pay. Minimum sustainable fuel‚Äìblending mandates have been introduced in some geographies, and several airlines have committed to SAF volumes of 10 to 30 percent of total jet fuel used by 2030, totaling about 5 percent of expected aviation fuel demand in 2030.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c73d9b2d-d540-4be6-873f-3712ee1fd6c5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c73d9b2d-d540-4be6-873f-3712ee1fd6c5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The McKinsey Global Energy Perspective model.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Notably, many airlines have expressed concerns around the cost, production, and timing of new SAF technologies and raised questions regarding where responsibility for spearheading and paying for these efforts lies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0b7ce6f8-ab2a-4931-8991-d1f288fc740e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0b7ce6f8-ab2a-4931-8991-d1f288fc740e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">"Qatar Airways CEO suggests 2050 net-zero goal beyond reach," Reuters, May 23, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span><sup>,</sup> <span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a34888c2-c68a-479d-bb7a-986ef37f910f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">21</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a34888c2-c68a-479d-bb7a-986ef37f910f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúBoeing CEO warns climate-friendly biofuels will ‚Äònever achieve the price of jet fuel‚Äô,‚Äù <em>Financial Times</em>, May 22, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Producers will need to scale different SAF-production technologies beyond those currently used because today‚Äôs feedstocks, such as waste oils, are limited in availability. These new technologies, which are often still in developmental phases, and the costs of crucial input parameters, such as renewable electricity and green hydrogen, will affect costs to produce SAF.</p>
<h3>Challenges influencing an MACC</h3>
<p><strong><em>Ever-changing regulations affect all solutions.</em></strong> It is important to recognize the full impact of regulations, such as SAF mandates and carbon taxes. Because an MACC displays only the marginal cost to the airline, a government-mandated increase in SAF at European airports, for example, will show an abatement impact in the curve but limited additional marginal costs to the airline. Still, it should be recognized that mandated SAF quotas could affect airlines‚Äô competitiveness compared to carriers operating through hubs outside of the mandate‚Äôs geography. Carbon taxes such as the EU Emissions Trading System have an amplifying effect on the identified actions: as taxes increase, it becomes more costly to operate in a traditional way and emission-reduction strategies become less costly.</p>
<p><strong><em>Quantifying levers is not easy.</em></strong> One challenge in developing an MACC lies in quantifying both the impact and estimating the associated cost of initiatives. MACCs are also not static; they look different every year. While the potential mitigation options for the aviation sector are relatively well known, the abatement opportunity and effective costs to airlines are typically not well quantified and are largely affected by many uncertainties in the market.</p>
<p><strong><em>Customer willingness to pay is growing.</em></strong> Cargo, corporate, and leisure customers have signaled or have the propensity to pay for decarbonization measures. A 2023 McKinsey survey<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a6a9fe05-9c9b-4bde-9670-3372c51ce512"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">22</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a6a9fe05-9c9b-4bde-9670-3372c51ce512" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">May 2023 report forthcoming. For an analysis from 2021, see Mishal Ahmad, Frederik Franz, Tomas Naucl√©r, and Daniel Riefer, ‚Äú<a href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/opportunities-for-industry-leaders-as-new-travelers-take-to-the-skies">Opportunities for industry leaders as new travelers take to the skies</a>,‚Äù McKinsey, April 5, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> indicated that 85 percent of travelers globally said they were willing to pay 2 percent or more for carbon-neutral flight tickets, which is a significant increase compared to previous years: in 2019 and 2021, a McKinsey survey showed consumers‚Äô willingness to pay more for carbon-neutral flight tickets was 46 and 39 percent, respectively. But consumers‚Äô actual behavior may differ. Another survey indicated that only 14 percent of travelers actually pay more for sustainable options when they travel.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="529beaea-83f5-4216-926f-b9fb17bb3fe8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">23</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="529beaea-83f5-4216-926f-b9fb17bb3fe8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em><a href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/accelerating-the-transition-to-net-zero-travel">Accelerating the transition to net-zero travel: Strategies for action</a></em>, a joint report from McKinsey and Skift, September 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Not only are consumer decisions subject to economic factors, but there is also a scarcity of sustainable booking options and unclear sustainability-related information. As such, raising ticket prices to factor in sustainable options could reduce demand or lead consumers to shift to other connections. Still, leading carriers could limit losing customers by creating transparency, debundling products, and driving personalized, sustainable offerings based on clear segmentation.</p>
<p>In addition to considering CO<sub>2</sub> abatement and the cost of certain actions, airlines can include additional sources and criteria in their decision making. For example, taking weight-reducing measures in the cabin to reduce CO<sub>2</sub> could have ramifications for an airline‚Äôs competitiveness and its customers‚Äô experience.</p>
<h3>Potential paths for OEMs in aviation decarbonization</h3>
<p>MACCs will take different shapes for different stakeholders, and most initiatives will require actors to work together. Aviation OEM MACCs will likely predominantly focus on Scope 3 Category 11 emissions (use of sold products). OEMs are also dependent on airlines taking measures to improve operational efficiency to fulfil their own downstream decarbonization potential. As such, OEMs can work with airlines to aggregate demand for SAF, for instance, to reduce fuel burn in the short term.</p>
<p>More revolutionary technologies, such as hydrogen and electric propulsion, will likely be limited to short-haul or few-passenger use cases until 2035, and the path to scaling these technologies remains uncertain.</p>
<h2>Considerations for implementation</h2>
<p>A dynamic and flexible approach to decarbonization allows stakeholders to consider changes in the market and draw implications from external ambiguity. Once companies have established targets and determined their priorities, they can take steps to make these goals more accessible. They can first recognize inherent uncertainties with regulatory landscapes, customer behavior, technology development, SAF availability and prices, and emissions. Then they can create scenarios and identify no-regret moves in the next one to three years.</p>
<p>To ensure rigorous implementation across the different departments‚Äîwhich is especially relevant for weight-saving measures, in which many operational departments play a role‚Äîairlines can benefit from a central governance structure to track and trace progress and steer where needed. Leading airlines integrate this as much as possible into their regular business planning cycles.</p>
<p>Some themes, however, may require a temporary thematic governance structure. One example is the optimization of SAF procurement, managing short-term and long-term offtake agreements, and long-term coinvestments. Another one is taking equity stakes to invest in advanced air mobility start-ups that will help them accomplish mid-term and long-term goals.</p>
<hr>
<p>Aviation companies that integrate decarbonization efforts into their standing business planning cycles can de-risk their sustainable transition and achieve optimized decarbonization costs. While decarbonizing the aviation industry is one of the largest challenges the industry has ever faced, the significant lead times of some investments heighten the urgency for companies across the aviation value chain to act quickly to position themselves better in the future. Airlines that embrace radical transparency on their decarbonization options and investigate partnerships with other aviation value-chain actors can determine the future of green aviation.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_79c2a62 mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_79c2a62 mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_79c2a62 mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_79c2a62 mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/axel-esque">Axel Esqu√©</a></strong> is a partner in McKinsey‚Äôs Paris office, <strong>Frederik Franz</strong> is a consultant in the Berlin office, <strong>Geert Mulder</strong> is an associate partner in the Amsterdam office, <strong><a href="/our-people/robin-riedel">Robin Riedel</a></strong> is a partner in the Bay Area office, and <strong>Daniel Riefer</strong> is a partner in the Munich office.</p>
<p>The authors would like to thank Andrea Cornell, Jeanne Ritter, Cameron Smith, and Jop Weterings for their contributions to this article.</p></div></div></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid aviation: Executing on net-zero goals"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":""},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Aviation has a difficult but imperative role in meeting net-zero goals. By prioritizing near- and long-term efforts, airlines and OEMs can refine decarbonization solutions and optimize their results."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Decarbonizing aviation is difficult but imperative to meet net-zero goals. By prioritizing near- and long-term efforts, airlines and OEMs can refine decarbonization solutions and optimize their results."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-06-16T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThough the aviation industry \u003c/strong\u003ehas committed to achieving net-zero flying by 2050,[[footnote 1]] its path to reaching that goal is complex.[[footnote 2]] The industry has aligned on most of the important actions needed to decarbonize\u0026mdash;namely, fleet renewal, disruptive propulsion technologies, operational efficiency, sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) usage, and carbon offsetting.[[footnote 3]] From 2005 to 2019, the aviation industry improved fuel efficiency by approximately 39 percent,[[footnote 4]] but absolute growth of emissions is larger than efficiency gains by far. Going forward, achieving decarbonization in a cost-effective way requires transparency and adaptability across a wide range of carbon mitigation measures as well as a clear focus on short-term versus long-term initiatives.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar authors]]\n\u003cp\u003eMany companies across the aviation value chain have set goals to be completed over the long term, but there are actions they can take today to move closer to accomplishing these objectives. To get started, companies should understand which actions to prioritize for the greatest impact and for a cost-optimal path to net-zero emissions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe current state of aviation decarbonization\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePrepandemic CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e emissions from aviation contributed to roughly 2.5 percent of global total emissions,[[footnote 5]] but the global-warming potential could be significantly greater (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Aviation and non-CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e emissions\u0026rdquo;). The sector is hard to abate because of unique requirements, including weight and size constraints, long innovation cycles, prioritization of safe operations, and because key technologies, such as SAFs, are relatively costly and have not been adopted at scale.[[footnote 6]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eMany stakeholders in the aviation value chain have committed to various sustainability goals, including emission-reduction targets,[[footnote 7]] SAF targets,[[footnote 8]] targets that include compensation,[[footnote 9]] and membership in coalitions.[[footnote 10]] In addition to the defined paths to reduce emissions that are in line with the Paris Agreement, the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi) has emerged as one of the leading standards (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;The Science Based Targets initiative\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eAs of April 2023, 25 airlines\u0026mdash;mostly based in the Americas and Europe\u0026mdash;have committed to setting or have set science-based targets. According to McKinsey analysis, this group represents more than 30 percent of global passenger traffic. On the OEM side, aerospace and defense companies, representing about 20 percent of the global value pool, have also committed to goals aligned with SBTi (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eWhile the ambitions are clear, actors in the aviation sector are highly dependent on each other to achieve their decarbonization commitments. For example, more than 95 percent of aircraft OEMs\u0026rsquo; emissions come from their Scope 3 Category 11 downstream emissions,[[footnote 11]]\u003csup\u003e,\u003c/sup\u003e [[footnote 12]] which is mostly airlines\u0026rsquo; fuel burn. This interdependency has strengthened the industry\u0026rsquo;s unified ambition to decarbonize, but it also highlights the role that actors such as commercial aviation lessors, OEMs, and suppliers need to play to support airlines and offer solutions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eFactors affecting decarbonization\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOptions for airlines to abate CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e emissions differ based on existing fleet efficiency, the network of the airline, and the baseline decarbonization efforts already implemented by the airline.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eFrom a technology perspective, the development to scale new SAF pathways with improved emission-reduction potential, such as advanced biofuels or power to liquid (PtL) fuels, is uncertain.[[footnote 13]] Biobased pathways face challenges in feedstock availability and collection to be immediately scalable, and PtL requires significant access to large amounts of renewable electricity. Other uncertainties remain about the progress in other technologies fields, such as new propulsion technology or advanced analytics for flight planning.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFrom a regulatory perspective, aviation players will need to adapt to the ever-changing implementation of regional incentives and penalties. For example, Europe\u0026rsquo;s reaction to the Inflation Reduction Act could change SAF-related decarbonization costs for European airlines.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOther industries such as marine and road transport, which are sourcing from the same sustainable fuel feedstock, also influence the aviation sector. This competition affects the balance of SAF supply and demand and therefore its market price, especially as the regulatory schemes and customer willingness to pay evolve.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMany decarbonization efforts also require investments with longer lead times that are not in line with traditional airline yearly business planning cycles and, as such, require a different view on economic and environmental returns. Although many airlines have shown strong financial results in 2022, outlooks are uncertain as the industry returns to pre-COVID-19 capacity levels, which drives traditional airlines to limit riskier investments despite their potential payoff beyond five-year financial plans.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese external factors have contributed to the struggle of companies across the aviation ecosystem to deploy multiple decarbonization efforts in the most cost-effective way, while managing uncertainties in parallel.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eIntroducing the marginal abatement cost curve\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs the timeline to hit near-term emission targets shortens, aviation sector players are increasingly searching for ways to achieve these goals\u0026mdash;and do so quickly to compensate for the long lead times of many initiatives. For example, solidifying sufficient access to affordable SAF can take several years, and renewing fleet quickly depends on OEMs\u0026rsquo; or lessors\u0026rsquo; ability to deliver or provide new aircraft.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eAs a first step, airlines can evaluate carbon abatement costs and impact potential by developing their own marginal abatement cost curve (MACC).[[footnote 14]] This assessment helps companies compare and sequence different decarbonization measures while also allowing for adjustments and updates. It also helps companies determine the best and most cost-effective decarbonization solutions for the industry (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Reading a marginal abatement cost curve\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCategories within a typical MACC for airlines\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExhibit 2 illustrates a typical MACC for an airline. Actions are classified by three categories: operational measures (including air traffic management), fleet renewal, and SAF.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eOperational measures.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Operational and efficiency measures often come at negative or low costs (due to associated fuel savings) but are limited in their impact.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAirlines can relatively easily enforce initiatives within their own control, such as introducing pilot incentive programs to fly and taxi more fuel efficiently or imposing stricter operational weight limits to reduce fuel needs. Bolder moves could affect customer experiences, such as reducing ultra-long-haul flights, removing some catering on short-haul flights, or densifying cabins to include more seats.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOther efficiency efforts are dependent on collaboration among several stakeholders, especially to optimize air space usage. For example, the Single European Sky program[[footnote 15]] aims to modernize air traffic control infrastructure to reduce up to 10 percent of emissions,[[footnote 16]] and a similar program called NextGen[[footnote 17]] is underway in the United States. However, an airline\u0026rsquo;s actual carbon emission savings depend on its exposure to the affected airspace, and emission reductions could be significantly lower than 10 percent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eFleet renewal.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Accelerated fleet rollover can come at negative marginal abatement cost, particularly when including the impact of regulatory action, such as future SAF mandates and kerosene taxes. Depending on the state of an airline\u0026rsquo;s fleet, the evolutionary rollover to already available aircraft types represents a decarbonization potential of up to 15 to 20 percent.[[footnote 18]] It is expected that next-generation aircraft, such as the Airbus A320neo or the Boeing 777-X family, will replace a significant share of current-generation aircraft in the next ten years (Exhibit 3).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eIn the long term, both OEMs and airlines could benefit from transitioning to more fuel-efficient aircraft and could adjust their prices to reflect greater fuel efficiency.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eSAF.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e SAF is by far the most impactful initiative, but financial effects vary due to mandates, subsidies, sourcing approaches, voluntary commitments, and customers\u0026rsquo; willingness to pay. Minimum sustainable fuel\u0026ndash;blending mandates have been introduced in some geographies, and several airlines have committed to SAF volumes of 10 to 30 percent of total jet fuel used by 2030, totaling about 5 percent of expected aviation fuel demand in 2030.[[footnote 19]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNotably, many airlines have expressed concerns around the cost, production, and timing of new SAF technologies and raised questions regarding where responsibility for spearheading and paying for these efforts lies.[[footnote 20]]\u003csup\u003e,\u003c/sup\u003e [[footnote 21]] Producers will need to scale different SAF-production technologies beyond those currently used because today\u0026rsquo;s feedstocks, such as waste oils, are limited in availability. These new technologies, which are often still in developmental phases, and the costs of crucial input parameters, such as renewable electricity and green hydrogen, will affect costs to produce SAF.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eChallenges influencing an MACC\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eEver-changing regulations affect all solutions.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e It is important to recognize the full impact of regulations, such as SAF mandates and carbon taxes. Because an MACC displays only the marginal cost to the airline, a government-mandated increase in SAF at European airports, for example, will show an abatement impact in the curve but limited additional marginal costs to the airline. Still, it should be recognized that mandated SAF quotas could affect airlines\u0026rsquo; competitiveness compared to carriers operating through hubs outside of the mandate\u0026rsquo;s geography. Carbon taxes such as the EU Emissions Trading System have an amplifying effect on the identified actions: as taxes increase, it becomes more costly to operate in a traditional way and emission-reduction strategies become less costly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eQuantifying levers is not easy.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e One challenge in developing an MACC lies in quantifying both the impact and estimating the associated cost of initiatives. MACCs are also not static; they look different every year. While the potential mitigation options for the aviation sector are relatively well known, the abatement opportunity and effective costs to airlines are typically not well quantified and are largely affected by many uncertainties in the market.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eCustomer willingness to pay is growing.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Cargo, corporate, and leisure customers have signaled or have the propensity to pay for decarbonization measures. A 2023 McKinsey survey[[footnote 22]] indicated that 85 percent of travelers globally said they were willing to pay 2 percent or more for carbon-neutral flight tickets, which is a significant increase compared to previous years: in 2019 and 2021, a McKinsey survey showed consumers\u0026rsquo; willingness to pay more for carbon-neutral flight tickets was 46 and 39 percent, respectively. But consumers\u0026rsquo; actual behavior may differ. Another survey indicated that only 14 percent of travelers actually pay more for sustainable options when they travel.[[footnote 23]] Not only are consumer decisions subject to economic factors, but there is also a scarcity of sustainable booking options and unclear sustainability-related information. As such, raising ticket prices to factor in sustainable options could reduce demand or lead consumers to shift to other connections. Still, leading carriers could limit losing customers by creating transparency, debundling products, and driving personalized, sustainable offerings based on clear segmentation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition to considering CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e abatement and the cost of certain actions, airlines can include additional sources and criteria in their decision making. For example, taking weight-reducing measures in the cabin to reduce CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e could have ramifications for an airline\u0026rsquo;s competitiveness and its customers\u0026rsquo; experience.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePotential paths for OEMs in aviation decarbonization\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMACCs will take different shapes for different stakeholders, and most initiatives will require actors to work together. Aviation OEM MACCs will likely predominantly focus on Scope 3 Category 11 emissions (use of sold products). OEMs are also dependent on airlines taking measures to improve operational efficiency to fulfil their own downstream decarbonization potential. As such, OEMs can work with airlines to aggregate demand for SAF, for instance, to reduce fuel burn in the short term.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMore revolutionary technologies, such as hydrogen and electric propulsion, will likely be limited to short-haul or few-passenger use cases until 2035, and the path to scaling these technologies remains uncertain.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eConsiderations for implementation\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA dynamic and flexible approach to decarbonization allows stakeholders to consider changes in the market and draw implications from external ambiguity. Once companies have established targets and determined their priorities, they can take steps to make these goals more accessible. They can first recognize inherent uncertainties with regulatory landscapes, customer behavior, technology development, SAF availability and prices, and emissions. Then they can create scenarios and identify no-regret moves in the next one to three years.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo ensure rigorous implementation across the different departments\u0026mdash;which is especially relevant for weight-saving measures, in which many operational departments play a role\u0026mdash;airlines can benefit from a central governance structure to track and trace progress and steer where needed. Leading airlines integrate this as much as possible into their regular business planning cycles.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSome themes, however, may require a temporary thematic governance structure. One example is the optimization of SAF procurement, managing short-term and long-term offtake agreements, and long-term coinvestments. Another one is taking equity stakes to invest in advanced air mobility start-ups that will help them accomplish mid-term and long-term goals.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAviation companies that integrate decarbonization efforts into their standing business planning cycles can de-risk their sustainable transition and achieve optimized decarbonization costs. While decarbonizing the aviation industry is one of the largest challenges the industry has ever faced, the significant lead times of some investments heighten the urgency for companies across the aviation value chain to act quickly to position themselves better in the future. Airlines that embrace radical transparency on their decarbonization options and investigate partnerships with other aviation value-chain actors can determine the future of green aviation.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":true},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-06-16T10:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFor example, the International Air Transport Association, International Civil Aviation Organization, and Civil Air Navigation Services Organisation all aim for net-zero aviation by 2050.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAxel Esqu\u0026eacute;, Adam Mitchell, Kritika Rastogi, and Robin Riedel, \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/decarbonizing-the-aviation-sector-making-net-zero-aviation-possible\"\u003eDecarbonizing the aviation sector: Making net zero aviation possible\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; addition to the CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e emissions produced from burning fuel, aviation affects the climate through emissions of nitrogen oxides (NO\u003csub\u003ex\u003c/sub\u003e), soot, and water vapor, which, among other effects, create contrails and cirrus clouds that cause radiation and affect the climate. The CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e emitted from kerosene burned in flight can stay in the upper atmosphere for 50 to 100 years, and NO\u003csub\u003ex\u003c/sub\u003e remain for several weeks, affecting the ozone layer.[[footnote 1]] As such, the total aviation effects may be approximately two to four times higher than the pure CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e effects would indicate.[[footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe science on non-CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e effects is nascent, so most airlines (and the latest Science Based Target initiative guidance) refer only to pure CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e emissions.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Aviation and non-CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e emissions"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eHydrogen-powered aviation: A fact-based study of hydrogen technology, economics, and climate impact by 2050\u003c/em\u003e, a joint report from the Clean Sky 2 and Fuel Cells and Hydrogen 2 Joint Undertakings, May 2020.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTarget true zero unlocking sustainable battery and hydrogen-powered flight\u003c/em\u003e, World Economic Forum (WEF), July 2022; M. R. Allen et al., \u0026ldquo;The contribution of global aviation to anthropogenic climate forcing for 2000 to 2018,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eAtmospheric Environment\u003c/em\u003e, January 2021, Volume 244.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"2"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eThe Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi) is a collaboration among four nongovernmental organizations: Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP), the United Nations Global Compact, World Resources Institute (WRI), and the World Wildlife Fund for Nature (WWF). The initiative aims to ensure emission-reduction targets set by companies are within the pace recommended by scientists to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. It also provides guidance and promotes best practices to reduce corporate greenhouse-gas emissions. As of April 2023, more than 4,500 companies have committed to or set science-based targets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRecently, the SBTi has provided guidance for an interim aviation 1.5¬∞ pathway, implying strict emission-reduction targets for airlines: namely, a more than 30 percent CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e reduction per revenue ton kilometer (RTK) by 2030 compared to 2019 base year levels and a more than 50 percent reduction by 2035.[[footnote 1]]\u003csup\u003e,\u003c/sup\u003e [[footnote 2]] In comparison, the International Energy Agency Net Zero Emissions pathway calls for approximately 38 percent emission reduction in 2030 and approximately 57 percent in 2035 compared to 2019 levels. Note that both pathways set targets for relative emissions only (measured per RTK).\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The Science Based Targets initiative"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBase year and target year vary by airline.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTechnical report: The SBTi interim 1.5¬∞ sector pathway for Aviation\u003c/em\u003e, Science Based Targets, February 2023. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"3"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eInitiatives are organized left to right on the marginal abatement cost curve (MACC) based on the economic cost of the initiative‚Äôs emissions abatement.
